title: Tyler Zhang
text: Hi, My name is Tyler. I believe the combination of geomatics and programming can drive meaningful change to the world!

title: Education
text:
Education

 University of British Columbia  Master of Geomatics for Environmental Management 2024-2025 
 University of Victoria B.Sc in Earth and Ocean Science 2016-2021 




Work Experience

 Sonar Data Analyst and Software Developer   July 2021 – Jan 2024  AquaCoustic Remote Technologies Inc.  Vancouver, BC

 
- Analyzed field-collected trunk sewer sonar data combined with GIS data to create accurate  maps, plots, and technical reports for infrastructure condition assessment.
- Supported the development and maintenance of GIS databases and optimized data processing software to improve efficiency and accuracy  

 Data Analyst January 2021 - May 2021 Fisheries and Oceans Canada Victoria, BC

 
-Developed python scripts for ocean water property data processing and provided accurate data and analysis for ocean environmental research.
-Developed and implemented automated QA/QC procedure for ocean water property data.
 

 Research Assistant  June 2019 - September 2019  Fisheries and Oceans Canada Victoria, BC

 
-Processed field collected fisheries acoustics data using developed MATLAB scripts. 
- Provided analysis and visualizations for juvenile salmon migration studies.



Competencies
Programming: Proficient in Python, R, and Swift with experience in data analysis, statistical modeling, and app development.
Software: Proficient in ArcGIS Pro, QGIS, Cloudcompare
Communication: Excellent communication skills developed through close collaboration with clients and team members, effectively identifying and addressing their needs.

title: Manhole Mate
text:
A free infrastructure Locating Software Design and developed by Tyler
 Manhole Mate provides an efficient way to access and manage infrastructure information and accurately locate assets on both Google Maps and GIS maps

This is a sample page where you can archive project deliverables. Every header you use will correspond to a tab in the legend - shown on the right-hand side of your screen (“On this page”).
If you’ve produced any GIS layers for your 599 project, this may be a good place to share them as interactive maps through leaflet. Alternatively, you can upload high-res figures showing correlations, box-plots, etc. from your report here, and provide a brief overview of key project results. If you have written some useful functions, you may also want to share those here to demonstrate proficiency in particular coding languages or synergies between notable coding packages.

Sample code snippet. Notice that you can provide a toggle to switch between coding languages - this is referred to as a ‘tabset’ in quarto. It is good practice to try and convert your R code to python, and vice-versa to demonstrate coding proficiency. For example, let’s showcase a function for calculating NDVI in R and Python.

RPython


calc_ndvi <- function(nir, red){ ndvi <- (nir-red)/(nir+red) return(ndvi) }


def calc_ndvi(nir, red): 
  ndvi = (nir.astype(float)-red.astype(float))/(nir.astype(float)+red.astype(float))
  return(ndvi)

title: Lidar Data Analysis
text: In this project, lidar data from MKRF research forest are used to generate high-resolution digital elevation models (DEM) and Canopy Height models (CHM) for terrain analysis, vegetation mapping, and various remote sensing applications.

title: Debris Hotspot Analysis in Howe Sound BC
text: Marine debris poses significant environmental and infrastructural risks, yet no studies have predicted debris accumulation patterns in Howe Sound. This research uses supervised classification of satellite imagery to analyze common landcover features of existing debris hotspots and develops a simulation model incorporating wind and river discharge as debris driving forces to predict future debris movement. By mapping debris pathways and identifying high-risk zones, this study aims to support conservation efforts and improve debris management strategies in the region.

title: Lidar Data Analysis
text:
Code Snippets

R


Raw_MKRF_Las <- readLAS("LAS/MKRF.las")
MKRF_Las_Filtered <- filter_duplicates(Raw_MKRF_Las)  #Removes Duplicated points

DEM_MKRF <- rasterize_terrain(MKRF_Las_Filtered, 2, tin())
DSM_MKRF <- rasterize_canopy(MKRF_Las_Filtered, res = 1, algorithm = p2r())

#CHM can be derived using DSM - DEM or using normalization method
Normalized_MHRF <- normalize_height(MKRF_Las_Filtered, DEM_MKRF)
CHM_MHRF <- rasterize_canopy(Normalized_MHRF, 2, p2r())

title: Lidar Data Analysis
text:
External links
You can also provide a frame linking to external websites. For example, here is a link to a Google Earth Engine application I developed. The full-screen GEE application is available here in case you’re interested.
(To use the GEE tool, navigate to any city you’d like, hit apply filters, and click anywhere on the map to retrieve a time-series of Landsat surface temperature observations for that point. Areas where the maximum temp exceeded 35 degrees Celsius in your date-range are highlighted in red.)

title: Lidar Data Analysis
text:
Method
 To generate the Digital Elevation Model (DEM) and Canopy Height Model (CHM), the lidar data stored in a .las file was first loaded and inspected using readLAS() and las_check(), identifying issues such as duplicate points, which were removed with filter_duplicates(). The Digital Elevation Model (DEM) was created using rasterize_terrain() with the tin() algorithm.
 The DSM was then generated by rasterizing the highest lidar returns with rasterize_canopy() , capturing the uppermost surfaces. Since the CHM represents vegetation height above the ground, the lidar point cloud was normalized using normalize_height(), which adjusted elevation values so that ground points were set to zero. Finally, the Canopy Height Model (CHM) was derived from the normalized LiDAR data using rasterize_canopy(), representing vegetation heights across the study area.

 Figure 2. Canopy Height Models (CHM) OF MKRF Research Forest

title: Debris Hotspot Analysis in Howe Sound BC
text:
Fig 1. Satellite images of Howe Sound on a winter and summer day at 10m resolution.









Fig 2. Supervised classification map comparing satellite images of Howe Sound on a winter and summer day.

title: Debris Hotspot Analysis in Howe Sound BC
text:
Method
 Multi-band satellite images at 20m resolution obtained from Copernicus were merged into a true-color composite raster image in ArcGIS Pro. Training data for six landcover types—vegetation, ocean water, river discharge, urban area, snow, and exposed rocks were manually created. The Maximum Likelihood Classification (MLC) and neural network algorithm were then applied to classify each pixel based on spectral characteristics.









Fig 1. Satellite images of Howe Sound on a winter and summer day at 10m resolution.
To predict future debris hotspots, a debris movement simulation model will be developed using a Howe Sound cartographic shapefile. The model will incorporate wind and river discharge as driving forces to visualize debris transport. Based on surface water variations Howe Sound will be divided into three sections: Northern Howe Sound (Squamish to Britannia Beach), Central Howe Sound (Britannia Beach to Anvil Island), and Southern Howe Sound (South Anvil Island to the Strait of Georgia). This division will help refine debris transport predictions.

title: Debris Hotspot Analysis in Howe Sound BC
text:
Result
 Figure 2 shows the classified maps of the Howe Sound study area, highlighting reduced snow cover in summer and lower river discharge in winter. These patterns suggest that river discharge drives debris accumulation in northern and central Howe Sound only during summer. Additionally, debris hotspots are primarily concentrated in urban areas, likely due to the reliance on local resident reports for identification. 









Fig 2. Supervised classification map comparing satellite images of Howe Sound on a winter and summer day.

title: Debris Hotspot Analysis in Howe Sound BC
text: Marine debris poses significant environmental and infrastructural risks, yet no studies have predicted debris accumulation patterns in Howe Sound. This research uses supervised classification of satellite imagery to analyze common landcover features of existing debris hotspots and develops a simulation model incorporating wind and river discharge as debris driving forces to predict future debris movement. By mapping debris pathways and identifying high-risk zones, this study aims to support conservation efforts and improve debris management strategies in the region.
